update.description:
Simulation iterations was not included in `State`. This pull requests adds it and add the following public functions to LogPlay:

* HasIterations() This is required for compatibility with old log files that doesn't have `<iterations>` in its state. During a playback, if a log file has `<iterations>`, the value contained in the log file is used to update the `iterations` value of the world. If the log file doesn't contain `<iterations>`, we assume that `iterations` start from 0 and we manually increment it in each log step.

* GetInitialIterations() Initial `<iterations>` value contained in the log file. This will be `0` if the log files does not have the `<iterations>` tag.
update.title: Add simulation iterations to state

content.raw: prerelease is built, should be safe to merge
content.html: prerelease is built, should be safe to merge

content.raw: I can't come up with a good reason off the top of my head. You could move time and iterations to only the WorldState, but that would touch a lot more code. You could make the change, or create an issue for this.
content.html: I can't come up with a good reason off the top of my head. You could move time and iterations to only the WorldState, but that would touch a lot more code. You could make the change, or create an issue for this.

content.raw: That's fine. If we don't add a default value, can you upgrade the Migration guide for the functions that have changed?
content.html: That's fine. If we don't add a default value, can you upgrade the Migration guide for the functions that have changed?

content.raw: I'm not 100% sure about this. A default parameter here will make the code to compile but you might get an unexpected state. If the code doesn't compile it's more evident to me that you have to include `iterations` as a new parameter.
content.html: I'm not 100% sure about this. A default parameter here will make the code to compile but you might get an unexpected state. If the code doesn't compile it's more evident to me that you have to include iterations as a new parameter.

content.raw: Since this is a breaking API change, should we add a default value to the new field? I don't know if any external people are using the `State` classes, but it would soften the blow.
content.html: Since this is a breaking API change, should we add a default value to the new field? I don't know if any external people are using the State classes, but it would soften the blow.

content.raw: It's now in line 515 but only executed if the log file does not have `iterations`. Otherwise, we just read the `iterations` value from the log.
content.html: It's now in line 515 but only executed if the log file does not have iterations. Otherwise, we just read the iterations value from the log.

content.raw: This code is removed. Is `this->dataPtr->iterations` updated somewhere else now?
content.html: This code is removed. Is this->dataPtr->iterations updated somewhere else now?

```
#!c++

Value of: iter->second
  Actual: "e4f109dcb78dbccc161614daee5f428519725ebb"

Which is: "159e58d1566adae48b751dc51fd66cbd1a9b736c"
```

content.raw: This is the "iterations when this state was generated" as described above, right? Maybe the description could be clearer here?
content.html: This is the "iterations when this state was generated" as described above, right? Maybe the description could be clearer here?

content.raw: I'm not sure if there's a use case for having a different `iterations` value in different links or joints. I followed the same approach that we were doing with `sim_time` and `real_time`. A potential reason for including it in `Joint`, `Link` and `Model` might be to encapsulate all the state within each class and not to spread the state between different classes. @nkoenig , is there any other reason for copying `wallTime`, `realTime`, `simTime` and `iterations` over all the XxxxState classes?
content.html: I'm not sure if there's a use case for having a different iterations value in different links or joints. I followed the same approach that we were doing with sim_time and real_time. A potential reason for including it in Joint, Link and Model might be to encapsulate all the state within each class and not to spread the state between different classes. @nkoenig , is there any other reason for copying wallTime, realTime, simTime and iterations over all the XxxxState classes?
